intro: Picris barbarorum, commonly known as the common wormwood, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small clusters of tiny flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with slender, branched stems and finely divided, gray-green leaves. Its flowers are yellow and bloom from June to August, attracting various pollinators. The plant has a strong, aromatic scent and has been used historically in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
